Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Complex, Spatially-patterned Tissue Structures from Stem Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Roy/ 1159326

In the past decade significant advances have been made in stem cell differentiation to create engineered tissues. However, most efforts to date have focused on regenerating a homogenous tissue structure whose bulk properties are similar to that of native tissues. But, most human tissues are complex, both structurally and functionally, and possess spatially-varying compositions and mechanical properties. Directing stem cells into such mature, three-dimensionally organized, complex tissues has not yet been achieved. A model example is articular cartilage, which has been widely studied in tissue engineering for several decades. Anatomically and functionally, articular cartilage consists of four, spatially distinct regions; the superficial, transitional, deep, and calcified zones. Each zone is characterized by unique extra-cellular matrix compositions, mechanical properties and cellular organization. Classical tissue engineering approaches for creating homogenous tissue replacements for articular cartilage has failed to achieve widespread clinical effectiveness because the engineered bulk properties do not mimic native tissue function. Based on recent findings that unique material compositions can be used to direct stem cells into specific types of chondrocytes that correspond to those from the various zones of articular cartilage, this project will explore a unique multi-layered hydrogel constructs with spatially varying biomaterial-niches for simultaneously differentiating a single stem cell population into a complex articular cartilage. The knowledge gathered would provide new insights on the feasibility of engineering complex, functionally-relevant tissues whose mechanical properties and composition can vary spatially.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: In the past decade significant advances have been made in stem cell differentiation to create engineered tissues. However, most efforts to date have focused on regenerating a homogeneous tissue structure whose bulk properties are similar to that of native tissues. But, most human tissues are complex, both structurally and functionally, and possess spatially-varying compositions and mechanical properties. Directing stem cells into such mature, three-dimensionally organized, complex tissues has not yet been achieved. A model example is articular cartilage, which has been widely studied in tissue engineering for several decades. Anatomically and functionally, articular cartilage consists of four, spatially distinct regions; the superficial, transitional, deep, and calcified zones. Each zone is characterized by unique extra-cellular matrix compositions, mechanical properties and cellular organization. Classical tissue engineering approaches for creating homogeneous tissue replacements for articular cartilage has failed to achieve widespread clinical effectiveness because the engineered bulk properties do not mimic native tissue function.

Based on recent findings that unique material compositions can be used to direct stem cells into specific types of chondrocytes that correspond to those from the various zones of articular cartilage, this project explored a unique multi-layered hydrogel constructs with spatially varying biomaterial-niches for simultaneously differentiating a single stem cell population into a complex articular cartilage. The knowledge gathered provided new insights on the feasibility of engineering complex, functionally-relevant tissues whose mechanical properties and composition can vary spatially. We generated data on how material composition alone can vary the type of neo-cartilage produced from the same human progenitor cell population when all other culture conditions are kept unchanged. We also investigated how normoxia and hypoxia as well as bioreactor culture conditions effect the quality of neo cartilage generated within the tested biomaterials. Finally we were able to generate multi-zonal cartilage tissue from donor-derived human bone marrow stromal cells that resembled some of the spatial architecture of native cartilage tissue, specifically the spatially varying matrix composition and mechanical properties. Our results provide a broad framework for creating human articular cartilage from bone marrow derived stromal cells with spatially varying properties that resemble the zonal architecture and in-vivo like spatial composition.

Broader Impact: Over the course of this grant, many trainees had the opportunity to learn about the motivation behind the project and train on different bioengineering techniques. Specifically, one postdoctoral fellow, one female engineering graduate student, four undergraduate students including one female engineering student, and three high school students including two female students and one underrepresented minority student; were trained. The results were disseminated in one international conference and one journal publication has been submitted. The broader concept of engineering spatially patterned complex tissue structures using patterned biomaterials with varying properties was also presented to undergraduate Biomedical and Chemical Engineering students in class. 



Last Modified: 04/01/2017
Modified by: Krishnendu Roy
